natural problem:
Find the point on the line defined by
\[\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -2 \\ 6 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}\]that is closest to the point $(2,3,4).$
natural solution: A point on the line is given by \[\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -2 \\ 6 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 4 - 2t \\ 6t \\ 1 - 3t \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]

The vector pointing from $(2,3,4)$ to $(4 - 2t, 6t, 1 - 3t)$ is then \[\begin{pmatrix} 2 - 2t \\ -3 + 6t \\ -3 - 3t \end{pmatrix}.\]For the point on the line that is closest to $(2,3,4),$ this vector will be orthogonal to the direction vector of the second line, which is $\begin{pmatrix} -2 \\ 6 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}.$  Thus, \[\begin{pmatrix} 2 - 2t \\ -3 + 6t \\ -3 - 3t \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} -2 \\ 6 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]This gives us $(2 - 2t)(-2) + (-3 + 6t)(6) + (-3 - 3t)(-3) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{13}{49}.$
For this value of $t,$ the point is $\boxed{\left( \frac{170}{49}, \frac{78}{49}, \frac{10}{49} \right)}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t :: real and p :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real^3"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. p t = (4 - 2 * t, 6 * t, 1 - 3 * t)"
and h1 : "min_distance (p t) (2, 3, 4)"
shows  "p t = (170 / 49, 78 / 49, 10 / 49)"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the point on the line defined by
\[\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -2 \\ 6 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}\]that is closest to the point $(2,3,4).$ The final Answer is \left( \frac{170}{49}, \frac{78}{49}, \frac{10}{49} \right)
 ### Proof
 A point on the line is given by \[\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -2 \\ 6 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 4 - 2t \\ 6t \\ 1 - 3t \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 unitsize (0.6 cm); pair A, B, C, D, E, F, H; A = (2,5); B = (0,0); C = (8,0); D = (A + reflect(B,C)*(A))/2; draw(A--D); draw((0,0)--(8,0)); dot("$(2,3,4)$", A, N); dot("$(4 - 2t, 6t, 1 - 3t)$", D, S); [/asy]
 The vector pointing from $(2,3,4)$ to $(4 - 2t, 6t, 1 - 3t)$ is then \[\begin{pmatrix} 2 - 2t \\ -3 + 6t \\ -3 - 3t \end{pmatrix}.\]For the point on the line that is closest to $(2,3,4),$ this vector will be orthogonal to the direction vector of the second line, which is $\begin{pmatrix} -2 \\ 6 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}.$  Thus, \[\begin{pmatrix} 2 - 2t \\ -3 + 6t \\ -3 - 3t \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} -2 \\ 6 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]This gives us $(2 - 2t)(-2) + (-3 + 6t)(6) + (-3 - 3t)(-3) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{13}{49}.$
 For this value of $t,$ the point is $\boxed{\left( \frac{170}{49}, \frac{78}{49}, \frac{10}{49} \right)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes t :: real and p :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real^3"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. p t = (4 - 2 * t, 6 * t, 1 - 3 * t)"
and h1 : "min_distance (p t) (2, 3, 4)"
shows  "p t = (170 / 49, 78 / 49, 10 / 49)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given a point $p(t)$ in 3D space with coordinates $(4 - 2t, 6t, 1 - 3t)$, find the value of $t$ such that the point $p(t)$ has the minimum distance to the point $(2, 3, 4)$. The coordinates of the point $p(t)$ at this minimum distance are $(\frac{170}{49}, \frac{78}{49}, \frac{10}{49})$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t :: real and v w :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "v = vector [4, 0, 1]"
and h1 : "w = vector [-2, 6, -3]"
and h2 : "norm ((v + t *\<^sub>R w) - vector [2, 3, 4]) = (LEAST d. \<exists> t. d = norm ((v + t *\<^sub>R w) - vector [2, 3, 4]))"
shows  "v + t *\<^sub>R w = vector [170 / 49, 78 / 49, 10 / 49]"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the point on the line defined by
\[\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -2 \\ 6 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}\]that is closest to the point $(2,3,4).$ The final Answer is \left( \frac{170}{49}, \frac{78}{49}, \frac{10}{49} \right)

 unitsize (0.6 cm); pair A, B, C, D, E, F, H; A = (2,5); B = (0,0); C = (8,0); D = (A + reflect(B,C)*(A))/2; draw(A--D); draw((0,0)--(8,0)); dot("$(2,3,4)$", A, N); dot("$(4 - 2t, 6t, 1 - 3t)$", D, S); [/asy]

 For this value of $t,$ the point is $\boxed{\left( \frac{170}{49}, \frac{78}{49}, \frac{10}{49} \right)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes t :: real and v w :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "v = vector [4, 0, 1]"
and h1 : "w = vector [-2, 6, -3]"
and h2 : "norm ((v + t *\<^sub>R w) - vector [2, 3, 4]) = (LEAST d. \<exists> t. d = norm ((v + t *\<^sub>R w) - vector [2, 3, 4]))"
shows  "v + t *\<^sub>R w = vector [170 / 49, 78 / 49, 10 / 49]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given vectors $v = [4, 0, 1]$ and $w = [-2, 6, -3]$, find the scalar $t$ such that the distance from the vector $v + tw$ to the vector $[2, 3, 4]$ is minimized. The vector that minimizes this distance is $[170/49, 78/49, 10/49]$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t :: real and P Q :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. P t = vector [4, 0, 1] + t *\<^sub>R vector [-2, 6, -3]"
and h1 : "Q = vector [2, 3, 4]"
and h2 : "\<exists> t_min. is_arg_min (distance Q (P t)) (\<lambda>t. true) t_min"
shows  "P (THE t_min. is_arg_min (distance Q (P t)) (\<lambda>t. true) t_min) = vector [170 / 49, 78 / 49, 10 / 49]"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the point on the line defined by
\[\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -2 \\ 6 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}\]that is closest to the point $(2,3,4).$ The final Answer is \left( \frac{170}{49}, \frac{78}{49}, \frac{10}{49} \right)

 unitsize (0.6 cm); pair A, B, C, D, E, F, H; A = (2,5); B = (0,0); C = (8,0); D = (A + reflect(B,C)*(A))/2; draw(A--D); draw((0,0)--(8,0)); dot("$(2,3,4)$", A, N); dot("$(4 - 2t, 6t, 1 - 3t)$", D, S); [/asy]

 For this value of $t,$ the point is $\boxed{\left( \frac{170}{49}, \frac{78}{49}, \frac{10}{49} \right)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes t :: real and P Q :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. P t = vector [4, 0, 1] + t *\<^sub>R vector [-2, 6, -3]"
and h1 : "Q = vector [2, 3, 4]"
and h2 : "\<exists> t_min. is_arg_min (distance Q (P t)) (\<lambda>t. true) t_min"
shows  "P (THE t_min. is_arg_min (distance Q (P t)) (\<lambda>t. true) t_min) = vector [170 / 49, 78 / 49, 10 / 49]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Consider a point P that moves along a line in three-dimensional space according to the equation P(t) = [4, 0, 1] + t * [-2, 6, -3]. If there is a stationary point Q at [2, 3, 4], find the position of P at the time t_min when P is closest to Q. The final Answer is [170/49, 78/49, 10/49].

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t :: real and a b c :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [4, 0, 1]"
and h1 : "b = vector [-2, 6, -3]"
and h2 : "c = vector [2, 3, 4]"
and h3 : "\<forall> t. c - (a + t *\<^sub>R b) = 0"
shows  "c = vector [170 / 49, 78 / 49, 10 / 49]"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

\[\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -2 \\ 6 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}\]that is closest to the point $(2,3,4).$ The final Answer is \left( \frac{170}{49}, \frac{78}{49}, \frac{10}{49} \right)

 unitsize (0.6 cm); pair A, B, C, D, E, F, H; A = (2,5); B = (0,0); C = (8,0); D = (A + reflect(B,C)*(A))/2; draw(A--D); draw((0,0)--(8,0)); dot("$(2,3,4)$", A, N); dot("$(4 - 2t, 6t, 1 - 3t)$", D, S); [/asy]

 For this value of $t,$ the point is $\boxed{\left( \frac{170}{49}, \frac{78}{49}, \frac{10}{49} \right)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes t :: real and a b c :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [4, 0, 1]"
and h1 : "b = vector [-2, 6, -3]"
and h2 : "c = vector [2, 3, 4]"
and h3 : "\<forall> t. c - (a + t *\<^sub>R b) = 0"
shows  "c = vector [170 / 49, 78 / 49, 10 / 49]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Find a value for $t$ such that the vector $c$ equals the vector $a$ plus $t$ times the vector $b$. Given that $a = [4, 0, 1]$, $b = [-2, 6, -3]$, and $c = [2, 3, 4]$. The final answer is $c = [\frac{170}{49}, \frac{78}{49}, \frac{10}{49}]$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. P t = (4 - 2 * t, 6 * t, 1 - 3 * t)"
and h1 : "Q = (2,3,4)"
and h2 : "\<forall> t. R t = sqrt ((P t \<bullet> Q) powr 2)"
shows  "t = 170 / 49" and "P t = (170 / 49, 78 / 49, 10 / 49)"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the point on the line defined by
\[\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -2 \\ 6 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}\]that is closest to the point $(2,3,4).$ The final Answer is \left( \frac{170}{49}, \frac{78}{49}, \frac{10}{49} \right)
 ### Proof
 A point on the line is given by \[\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -2 \\ 6 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 4 - 2t \\ 6t \\ 1 - 3t \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 unitsize (0.6 cm); pair A, B, C, D, E, F, H; A = (2,5); B = (0,0); C = (8,0); D = (A + reflect(B,C)*(A))/2; draw(A--D); draw((0,0)--(8,0)); dot("$(2,3,4)$", A, N); dot("$(4 - 2t, 6t, 1 - 3t)$", D, S); [/asy]
 The vector pointing from $(2,3,4)$ to $(4 - 2t, 6t, 1 - 3t)$ is then \[\begin{pmatrix} 2 - 2t \\ -3 + 6t \\ -3 - 3t \end{pmatrix}.\]For the point on the line that is closest to $(2,3,4),$ this vector will be orthogonal to the direction vector of the second line, which is $\begin{pmatrix} -2 \\ 6 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}.$  Thus, \[\begin{pmatrix} 2 - 2t \\ -3 + 6t \\ -3 - 3t \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} -2 \\ 6 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]This gives us $(2 - 2t)(-2) + (-3 + 6t)(6) + (-3 - 3t)(-3) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{13}{49}.$
 For this value of $t,$ the point is $\boxed{\left( \frac{170}{49}, \frac{78}{49}, \frac{10}{49} \right)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes t :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. P t = (4 - 2 * t, 6 * t, 1 - 3 * t)"
and h1 : "Q = (2,3,4)"
and h2 : "\<forall> t. R t = sqrt ((P t \<bullet> Q) powr 2)"
shows  "t = 170 / 49" and "P t = (170 / 49, 78 / 49, 10 / 49)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Given a function $P(t) = (4 - 2t, 6t, 1 - 3t)$ and a constant vector $Q = (2,3,4)$, find a value for $t$ such that $R(t) = \sqrt{(P(t) \cdot Q)^2}$, where $\cdot$ denotes the dot product. The final answer is $t = \frac{170}{49}$ and $P(t) = \left(\frac{170}{49}, \frac{78}{49}, \frac{10}{49}\right)$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t :: real and v :: "real \<Rightarrow> real^3"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. v t = vector [4, 0, 1] + t *\<^sub>R vector [-2, 6, -3]"
and h1 : "norm (v t - vector [2, 3, 4]) = (LEAST d. \<exists> t. d = norm (v t - vector [2, 3, 4]))"

(* ### Problem

\[\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -2 \\ 6 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}\]that is closest to the point $(2,3,4).$ The final Answer is \left( \frac{170}{49}, \frac{78}{49}, \frac{10}{49} \right)

 For this value of $t,$ the point is $\boxed{\left( \frac{170}{49}, \frac{78}{49}, \frac{10}{49} \right)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes t :: real and v :: "real \<Rightarrow> real^3"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. v t = vector [4, 0, 1] + t *\<^sub>R vector [-2, 6, -3]"
and h1 : "norm (v t - vector [2, 3, 4]) = (LEAST d. \<exists> t. d = norm (v t - vector [2, 3, 4]))"
shows  "v t = vector [170/49, 78/49, 10/49]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

a_6.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes t :: real and P Q :: "real*real*real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. P t = (4 - 2*t, 6*t, 1 - 3*t)"
and h1 : "Q = (2,3,4)"
and h2 : "\<forall> t1 t2. dist (P t1) Q \<le> dist (P t2) Q"

 For this value of $t,$ the point is $\boxed{\left( \frac{170}{49}, \frac{78}{49}, \frac{10}{49} \right)}.$
 *)

theorem 
fixes t :: real and P Q :: "real*real*real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. P t = (4 - 2*t, 6*t, 1 - 3*t)"
and h1 : "Q = (2,3,4)"
and h2 : "\<forall> t1 t2. dist (P t1) Q \<le> dist (P t2) Q"
shows  "P t = (170 / 49, 78 / 49, 10 / 49)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given a point Q at (2,3,4) and a moving point P(t) whose coordinates are given by (4 - 2t, 6t, 1 - 3t), find the value of t where P(t) is at its closest to Q. The final answer is (170/49, 78/49, 10/49).

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real^3"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. P t = vector [4 - 2 * t, 6 * t, 1 - 3 * t]"
and h1 : "Q t = vector [2, 3, 4]"
and h2 : "t = (GREATEST t. norm (Q t - P t))"
shows  "P t = vector [170 / 49, 78 / 49, 10 / 49]"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the point on the line defined by
\[\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -2 \\ 6 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}\]that is closest to the point $(2,3,4).$ The final Answer is \left( \frac{170}{49}, \frac{78}{49}, \frac{10}{49} \right)

 For this value of $t,$ the point is $\boxed{\left( \frac{170}{49}, \frac{78}{49}, \frac{10}{49} \right)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes t :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real^3"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. P t = vector [4 - 2 * t, 6 * t, 1 - 3 * t]"
and h1 : "Q t = vector [2, 3, 4]"
and h2 : "t = (GREATEST t. norm (Q t - P t))"
shows  "P t = vector [170 / 49, 78 / 49, 10 / 49]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given two vector-valued functions $P$ and $Q$ defined as follows: $P(t) = \langle 4 - 2t, 6t, 1 - 3t \rangle$ and $Q(t) = \langle 2, 3, 4 \rangle$, find the value of $t$ that maximizes the norm of the difference between $Q(t)$ and $P(t)$. What is the vector $P(t)$ at this value of $t$? The final answer is $\langle \frac{170}{49}, \frac{78}{49}, \frac{10}{49} \rangle$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t :: real and point :: "real * real * real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. point t = (4 - 2 * t, 6 * t, 1 - 3 * t)"
and h1 : "is_norm (2,3,4) point t"
shows  "point t = (170 / 49, 78 / 49, 10 / 49)"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the point on the line defined by
\[\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -2 \\ 6 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}\]that is closest to the point $(2,3,4).$ The final Answer is \left( \frac{170}{49}, \frac{78}{49}, \frac{10}{49} \right)
 ### Proof
 A point on the line is given by \[\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -2 \\ 6 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 4 - 2t \\ 6t \\ 1 - 3t \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 unitsize (0.6 cm); pair A, B, C, D, E, F, H; A = (2,5); B = (0,0); C = (8,0); D = (A + reflect(B,C)*(A))/2; draw(A--D); draw((0,0)--(8,0)); dot("$(2,3,4)$", A, N); dot("$(4 - 2t, 6t, 1 - 3t)$", D, S); [/asy]
 The vector pointing from $(2,3,4)$ to $(4 - 2t, 6t, 1 - 3t)$ is then \[\begin{pmatrix} 2 - 2t \\ -3 + 6t \\ -3 - 3t \end{pmatrix}.\]For the point on the line that is closest to $(2,3,4),$ this vector will be orthogonal to the direction vector of the second line, which is $\begin{pmatrix} -2 \\ 6 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}.$  Thus, \[\begin{pmatrix} 2 - 2t \\ -3 + 6t \\ -3 - 3t \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} -2 \\ 6 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]This gives us $(2 - 2t)(-2) + (-3 + 6t)(6) + (-3 - 3t)(-3) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{13}{49}.$
 For this value of $t,$ the point is $\boxed{\left( \frac{170}{49}, \frac{78}{49}, \frac{10}{49} \right)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes t :: real and point :: "real * real * real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. point t = (4 - 2 * t, 6 * t, 1 - 3 * t)"
and h1 : "is_norm (2,3,4) point t"
shows  "point t = (170 / 49, 78 / 49, 10 / 49)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given a point in three-dimensional space that moves according to the function $(4 - 2t, 6t, 1 - 3t)$, find the time $t$ at which this point is orthogonal to the vector $(2,3,4)$. The final answer is $(\frac{170}{49}, \frac{78}{49}, \frac{10}{49})$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real^3"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. P t = vector [4, 0, 1] + t *\<^sub>R vector [-2, 6, -3]"
and h1 : "Q = vector [2, 3, 4]"
and h2 : "is_arg_min (\<lambda> t. dist (P t) Q) UNIV t"
shows  "P t = vector [170 / 49, 78 / 49, 10 / 49]"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the point on the line defined by
\[\begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -2 \\ 6 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}\]that is closest to the point $(2,3,4).$ The final Answer is \left( \frac{170}{49}, \frac{78}{49}, \frac{10}{49} \right)
 ### Proof
 A point on the line is given by \[\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} -2 \\ 6 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 4 - 2t \\ 6t \\ 1 - 3t \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 unitsize (0.6 cm); pair A, B, C, D, E, F, H; A = (2,5); B = (0,0); C = (8,0); D = (A + reflect(B,C)*(A))/2; draw(A--D); draw((0,0)--(8,0)); dot("$(2,3,4)$", A, N); dot("$(4 - 2t, 6t, 1 - 3t)$", D, S); [/asy]
 The vector pointing from $(2,3,4)$ to $(4 - 2t, 6t, 1 - 3t)$ is then \[\begin{pmatrix} 2 - 2t \\ -3 + 6t \\ -3 - 3t \end{pmatrix}.\]For the point on the line that is closest to $(2,3,4),$ this vector will be orthogonal to the direction vector of the second line, which is $\begin{pmatrix} -2 \\ 6 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}.$  Thus, \[\begin{pmatrix} 2 - 2t \\ -3 + 6t \\ -3 - 3t \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} -2 \\ 6 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]This gives us $(2 - 2t)(-2) + (-3 + 6t)(6) + (-3 - 3t)(-3) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{13}{49}.$
 For this value of $t,$ the point is $\boxed{\left( \frac{170}{49}, \frac{78}{49}, \frac{10}{49} \right)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes t :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real^3"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. P t = vector [4, 0, 1] + t *\<^sub>R vector [-2, 6, -3]"
and h1 : "Q = vector [2, 3, 4]"
and h2 : "is_arg_min (\<lambda> t. dist (P t) Q) UNIV t"
shows  "P t = vector [170 / 49, 78 / 49, 10 / 49]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given a vector function P(t) = [4, 0, 1] + t * [-2, 6, -3] and a fixed vector Q = [2, 3, 4], find the value of P(t) that minimizes the Euclidean distance from P(t) to Q. The final answer is P(t) = [170/49, 78/49, 10/49].
